title: European Union law
context: While the Treaties and Regulations will have direct effect (if clear, unconditional and immediate), Directives do not generally give citizens (as opposed to the member state) standing to sue other citizens. In theory, this is because TFEU article 288 says Directives are addressed to the member states and usually "leave to the national authorities the choice of form and methods" to implement. In part this reflects that directives often create minimum standards, leaving member states to apply higher standards. For example, the Working Time Directive requires that every worker has at least 4 weeks paid holidays each year, but most member states require more than 28 days in national law. However, on the current position adopted by the Court of Justice, citizens have standing to make claims based on national laws that implement Directives, but not from Directives themselves. Directives do not have so called "horizontal" direct effect (i.e. between non-state parties). This view was instantly controversial, and in the early 1990s three Advocate Generals persuasively argued that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens. The Court of Justice refused, but there are five large exceptions.

questions.question: What generally does not allow citizens to sue other citizens?
How many paid holiday days does the Working Time directive require workers to have each year?

When did the three Advocate Generals argue that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens?

completions:
The European Union is composed of various laws, regulations, and directives. These documents dictate the functioning and operations of member states, ensuring a structured and harmonious partnership among them. While certain Treaties and Regulations have clear, unconditional, and immediate effects, Directives may not directly benefit individual citizens in the same way. Directives, as stated in Article 288 of the Treaty for the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), are primarily addressed to member states, allowing them to choose their preferred form and method of implementation. This is in line with the directive's intention to set minimum standards, enabling member states to apply higher standards if they so choose. For instance, the Working Time Directive mandates a minimum of four weeks' paid vacation annually for every worker; however, most member states have enacted even more stringent holiday regulations.

It is important to note that citizens do not have the right to sue other citizens based on Directives. The Treaties and Regulations grant clear, direct effect to citizens, while Directives focus on the responsibilities of member states. Although Directives do not inherently possess "horizontal" direct effect, meaning they do not create rights and duties between non-state parties, there are notable exceptions. The Court of Justice has ruled that citizens can claim rights based on national laws that implement Directives, but not directly from the directives themselves. This stance has been highly debated, as three Advocate Generals in the early 1990s argued that Directives should establish rights and obligations for all citizens. Despite their arguments, the Court of Justice upheld its decision, considering that Directives were primarily intended for member states rather than individual citizens.

In conclusion, while the European Union has a comprehensive set of laws, regulations, and directives governing the functioning and operations of its member states, these documents differ in their direct impact on citizens. Treaties and Regulations directly affect citizens, whereas Directives primarily focus on the responsibilities of member states. The lack of direct effect of Directives on citizens has been a topic of controversy, with some advocating for a more comprehensive approach that grants citizens standing to sue based on Directives. However, the current stance of the Court of Justice remains in place, emphasizing the distinction between these various legal instruments and their respective roles within the European Union framework.

title: 1973 oil crisis

title: Genghis Khan
context: Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolia's history. He is responsible for the emergence of the Mongols as a political and ethnic identity because there was no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity. He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of almost endemic warfare between tribes. He is also given credit for the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law. "Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Khans time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters related to corruption and bribery very heavily," Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted. President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anti-corruption efforts as Genghis Khan sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth. "Chinggis (Genghis Khan)...was a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law, and not with the distinctions between people. He was a man who knew that the good laws and rules lived longer than fancy palaces," Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaan's birth. In summary, Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.

Rewritten passages:

title: Chloroplast
context: While primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor, secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two, as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event, when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest itmuch like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story. The engulfed alga was broken down, leaving only its chloroplast, and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus, forming a chloroplast with three or four membranesthe two cyanobacterial membranes, sometimes the eaten alga's cell membrane, and the phagosomal vacuole from the host's cell membrane.

questions.question: What kind of membrane do primary chloroplasts have?
What differs about secondary chloroplasts' membranes?
questions.answer: additional membranes outside of the original two

questions.question: What was the secondary endosymbiotic event?
questions.answer: a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it

questions.question: What additional membranes do secondary chloroplasts have?
questions.answer: sometimes the eaten alga's cell membrane, and the phagosomal vacuole from the host's cell membrane

questions.question: What was left when engulfed algae was broken down?
questions.answer: its chloroplast, and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus

completions: Chloroplasts are organelles found in plant cells that play a crucial role in photosynthesis, the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy. These organelles have a double membrane structure, which is a remnant of their cyanobacterial ancestor. Some chloroplasts, known as secondary chloroplasts, have additional membranes outside of the original two, as a result of a secondary endosymbiotic event. This occurs when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote successfully engulfs a chloroplast-containing alga, but fails to digest it. The engulfed alga is eventually broken down, leaving only its chloroplast, and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus. Rewritten passages:

title: Yuan dynasty
context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, Song, as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: ) to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local government institutions, however, showed a major overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was (directly or indirectly) responsible for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries), was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was established (such as during the reign of Klg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

Yuan Dynasty Bureaucracy
The system of bureaucracy established by Kublai Khan drew upon diverse cultural influences, including those from the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the formal terminology of the institutions might suggest a purely Chinese dynastic structure, the Yuan bureaucracy was a blend of elements from different cultures. Chinese advisors like Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu played a significant role in shaping the early court of Kublai, and the central government administration was set up within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) for handling civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: ) for managing military affairs, and the Censorate for conducting internal surveillance and inspection. However, the actual functions of both central and local government institutions demonstrated a significant overlap between civil and military jurisdictions, reflecting the Mongol tradition of relying heavily on military institutions and offices for governance. Despite this, a primarily civilian bureaucracy emerged, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution responsible for most other government agencies, such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries. At times, another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) focused on finance was established (e.g., during the reign of Klg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but it was generally abandoned shortly afterwards.

title: Scottish Parliament
context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

title: Chloroplast
context: Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma. The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.

Passage:
Chloroplast
Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma. The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.

title: Imperialism
context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Imperialism: an Overview
Imperialism has been a topic of interest for centuries, with many different definitions and interpretations. In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was first introduced into English in the late 1870s by opponents of British prime minister Benjamin Disraeli's imperial policies. However, it was soon adopted by those who supported the idea of imperialism, such as Joseph Chamberlain. Some saw imperialism as a way to promote idealism and philanthropy, while others believed it was driven by political self-interest and capitalist greed. Noted theorists such as John A. Hobson and Vladimir Lenin provided more macroeconomic connotations to the term, often portraying imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism. Many modern theoreticians continue to emphasize the structural or systemic character of imperialism, and often extend its time period to centuries, dating back to events such as Christopher Columbus and the Crusades. Overall, the concept of imperialism has evolved significantly, reflecting changes in sensibility and attitudes towards power.
Imperialism: Historical Context and Evolution
Imperialism has a rich and complex history, with its origins dating back to ancient civilizations. However, the term as it is commonly used today was first popularized in the late 19th century, during a period of intense colonial expansion by European powers. This era is often referred to as the "Age of Imperialism," and it saw the establishment of vast empires across the globe, including the British Empire, the French Empire, and the German Empire. As the application of the term has expanded, so too has its meaning, encompassing not only the physical and political aspects of imperialism, but also its moral, economic, systemic, and cultural dimensions. Today, imperialism is seen as a complex and multifaceted phenomenon, with deep roots in the history of the world. 
Imperialism: A Systemic Feature of Capitalism
In his seminal work "Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism," Vladimir Lenin argued that imperialism is a natural extension of capitalism, driven by the need for capitalist economies to expand their investment, resources, and labor force. This view has been widely influential in subsequent discussions of imperialism, with many Marxist theorists seeing it as a structural feature of the capitalist system. According to this perspective, imperialism is not merely a set of policies or actions taken by individual states, but a systemic phenomenon that is deeply embedded in the economic and political structures of the global capitalist system. This understanding of imperialism as a systemic feature has helped to shed light on the underlying dynamics of the international system, and has contributed to a greater understanding of the ways in which power is distributed and maintained in the modern world.
Imperialism: A Complex and Evolving Concept
The concept of imperialism has undergone significant changes over time, reflecting shifts in sensibility and attitudes towards power. In the late 19th century, imperialism was often seen as a tool for promoting idealism and philanthropy, and was associated with the expansionist policies of figures like British prime minister Benjamin Disraeli. However, as the century progressed, the negative aspects of imperialism became increasingly apparent, and the term took on a more negative connotation. Today, imperialism is seen as a complex and multifaceted phenomenon, encompassing a range of moral, economic, systemic, and cultural dimensions. This evolution in the understanding of imperialism reflects a growing recognition of the interconnectedness of global politics and economics, and the need to develop a more nuanced and comprehensive approach to understanding and addressing the challenges posed by imperialism in the 21st century.

This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism has been widely adopted by later Marxist theoreticians.

Many theoreticians on the left have emphasized the systemic or structural character of "imperialism," suggesting that it extends beyond a specific policy or brief period in the late 19th century, encompassing an entire world system that dates back to historical events such as Christopher Columbus' voyages and the Crusades. The expanded application of the term has shifted its meaning along five distinct axes: the moral, economic, systemic, cultural, and temporal. This reflects a growing discomfort with the idea of power and its role in shaping world events.

title: Huguenot
context: A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besanon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise. The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

The use of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally meaning housemates) may have been incorporated, alluding to the similarities with the German word Eidgenosse, which refers to confederates in the Swiss Confederacy. Geneva, the adopted home of John Calvin and the center of the Calvinist movement, also contributed to the confusion surrounding the term Huguenot. In Geneva, Hugues, despite being a Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party," which advocated for independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was allegedly first applied in France to those conspirators, who were all aristocratic members of the Reformed Church and involved in the foiled Amboise plot of 1560. This plot aimed to seize power from the influential House of Guise and foster relations with the Swiss. Thus, the combination of Hugues and Eidgenosse led to the formation of the term Huguenot, which connected the Protestant cause with unpopular politics in France. [citation needed]

Can you provide more information about the ideology of Wahhabi/Salafi jihadism?
Wahhabi/Salafi jihadism is an extremist ideology that is based on a strict interpretation of Islamic beliefs and seeks to establish a global Islamic caliphate through violent means. Wahhabism is a sect of Sunni Islam that originated in Saudi Arabia in the 18th century, and it is characterized by its rejection of traditional Islamic practices and beliefs that are not in line with its strict interpretation of the Quran and Sunnah (the teachings and practices of the Prophet Muhammad).

Salafi jihadism, on the other hand, is a more modern offshoot of Wahhabism that emerged in the 20th century. Salafi jihadism advocates for the establishment of a global Islamic caliphate by using violent means, including terrorism, to achieve its goals. It is characterized by its rejection of modernity, democracy, and Western values, and its belief in the superiority of Islamic law (Sharia) over all other systems of law.

Wahhabi/Salafi jihadism has been responsible for a number of violent acts around the world, including the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States, the 2004 Beslan school siege in Russia, and the 2015 Paris attacks. Many of the leaders and members of Wahhabi/Salafi jihadist groups, including the Islamic State, have been associated with these and other violent acts.

In December 2014, President Uhuru Kenyatta signed a Security Laws Amendment Bill, which supporters of the law suggested was necessary to guard against armed groups. Opposition politicians, human rights groups, and nine Western countries criticised the security bill, arguing that it infringed on democratic freedoms. The governments of the United States, Britain, Germany and France also collectively issued a press statement cautioning about the law's potential impact. Through the Jubillee Coalition, the Bill was later passed on 19 December in the National Assembly under acrimonious circumstances.

Martin Luther: A Man of Faith and Translation

Introduction:
Martin Luther was a prominent figure in the Protestant Reformation, whose work in translating the Bible into German greatly influenced the religious landscape of the time. His translations were not only groundbreaking but also deeply influenced by his own beliefs and teachings.

1. Translation of the New Testament:
In 1522, Luther published his German translation of the New Testament. This marked a significant milestone in the dissemination of the Bible to the common people, allowing them to read and understand the scriptures in their native language. Luther's translation was not only a linguistic achievement but also a reflection of his theological perspectives.

2. Completion of the Old Testament:
Luther and his collaborators worked tirelessly to translate the Old Testament into German. The completion of this translation in 1534 was a major accomplishment, as it allowed for a comprehensive and accessible version of the entire Bible in the German language. Luther continued to refine his translation until the end of his life, ensuring that it accurately conveyed the intended message.

3. Insertion of "alone" in Romans 3:28:
One of the most controversial aspects of Luther's translation was his decision to insert the word "alone" after "faith" in Romans 3:28. This addition was met with criticism, as it emphasized the idea that salvation comes solely through faith in Christ, without the need for works of the Law. Luther defended his choice, stating that the text and the meaning of St. Paul demanded it. This interpretation was pivotal in asserting the importance of faith alone as the basis for justification.

4. The main point of Christian doctrine:
Luther recognized that the main point of Christian doctrine was the justification of believers through faith in Christ. By emphasizing the cutting away of works, he highlighted the significance of faith alone in achieving salvation. Consequently, Luther believed that it was essential to express this concept clearly and concisely, leading to his decision to insert "alone" in the translation of Romans 3:28.

In conclusion, Martin Luther's translations of the Bible, particularly his New and Old Testaments, were not only linguistically significant but also deeply tied to his own religious beliefs and teachings. His insistence on the importance of faith alone in achieving salvation through the insertion of "alone" in Romans 3:28 exemplifies his commitment to accurately conveying the message of the Bible to the German-speaking community.

title: Prime number
context: Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number, so they could not consider it to be a prime. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number. In the mid-18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler -- who did not agree. In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime. For example, Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,006,721, reprinted as late as 1956, started with 1 as its first prime. Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime. By the early 20th century, mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number, but rather forms its own special category as a "unit".

**Version 1**
Prime Number Definition: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. The concept of a prime number is fundamental in number theory, with applications in various fields such as cryptography, computer science, and physics.

**Version 2**
History of Prime Numbers: The ancient Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, which led to some confusion about whether 1 should be classified as a prime number or not. This debate continued throughout the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, with some mathematicians including 1 as the first prime number. However, by the mid-19th century, most mathematicians had agreed that 1 is not a prime number, but rather a "unit" that forms its own category. Despite this consensus, there were still some notable exceptions, such as Christian Goldbach, who listed 1 as the first prime in his correspondence with Leonhard Euler.

**Version 3**
Prime Numbers and 1: The question of whether 1 is a prime number has been a subject of debate among mathematicians for centuries. While some early Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, many mathematicians throughout history have included 1 as the first prime number. However, by the 19th century, the majority of mathematicians had come to the conclusion that 1 is not a prime number, but rather a "unit" that stands alone. This distinction is important in number theory, as prime numbers play a crucial role in many mathematical concepts and applications, such as cryptography and computer science.

**Version 4**
The Special Case of 1: In the realm of mathematics, 1 is often treated as a special case when discussing prime numbers. While many early mathematicians included 1 as a prime number, the modern consensus is that 1 is not a prime number, but rather a "unit" that forms its own category. This distinction is important in number theory, as prime numbers are essential building blocks in the study of integers and their properties. By recognizing 1 as a unique case, mathematicians can more accurately describe the behavior and relationships between prime numbers and other numbers.

Most early Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, so they couldn't call it a prime. However, by the Middle Ages and Renaissance, many mathematicians did consider 1 to be the first prime number. Prime numbers have been a subject of great interest in mathematics for centuries. The concept of prime numbers has undergone several changes over time, reflecting the evolving understanding of mathematicians. Most early Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, and therefore, they could not classify it as a prime number. However, as time progressed, the perception of what constitutes a prime number changed. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance, many mathematicians began to include 1 as the first prime number. One notable mathematician who supported this view was Christian Goldbach, who listed 1 as the first prime in his correspondence with Leonhard Euler. Despite Goldbach's support, Euler himself did not agree with the classification of 1 as a prime number.

The debate surrounding the primality of 1 continued into the 19th century, with many mathematicians still considering it to be a prime. One such mathematician was Derrick Norman Lehmer, who compiled a list of primes up to 10,067,211 and republished it as late as 1956. His list began with 1 as its first prime number. Another mathematician, Henri Lebesgue, is often credited as the last professional mathematician to consider 1 a prime number. However, by the early 20th century, the majority of mathematicians had come to accept that 1 is not a prime number. Instead, it was recognized as a unique entity, separate from prime numbers, and referred to as a "unit". This change in understanding marked a significant shift in the way mathematicians approached the concept of prime numbers, highlighting the ongoing evolution of mathematical knowledge and its impact on our understanding of fundamental concepts.

In conclusion, the concept of prime numbers has undergone significant changes over time, reflecting the evolving understanding of mathematicians. While most early Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, and therefore, not a prime, by the Middle Ages and Renaissance, many mathematicians began to include 1 as the first prime number. However, by the 19th century, as the understanding of prime numbers continued to evolve, most mathematicians accepted that 1 is not a prime number but a unit. This shift in perspective highlights the ongoing nature of mathematical discovery and the importance of re-evaluating and revising our understanding of fundamental concepts as new evidence and insights emerge.

Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number, so they could not consider it to be a prime. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number. In the mid-18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler -- who did not agree. In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime. For example, Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,006,721, reprinted as late as 1956, started with 1 as its first prime. Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime. By the early 20th century, mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number, but rather forms its own special category as a "unit".

title: French and Indian War
context: In the spring of 1753, Paul Marin de la Malgue was given command of a 2,000-man force of Troupes de la Marine and Indians. His orders were to protect the King's land in the Ohio Valley from the British. Marin followed the route that Cloron had mapped out four years earlier, but where Cloron had limited the record of French claims to the burial of lead plates, Marin constructed and garrisoned forts. He first constructed Fort Presque Isle (near present-day Erie, Pennsylvania) on Lake Erie's south shore. He had a road built to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. Marin constructed a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf (present-day Waterford, Pennsylvania), designed to guard the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. As he moved south, he drove off or captured British traders, alarming both the British and the Iroquois. Tanaghrisson, a chief of the Mingo, who were remnants of Iroquois and other tribes who had been driven west by colonial expansion. He intensely disliked the French (whom he accused of killing and eating his father). Traveling to Fort Le Boeuf, he threatened the French with military action, which Marin contemptuously dismissed.

In the year 1753, a man named Paul Marin de la Malgue was in charge of a big group of soldiers. He was asked by the king to protect the land in the Ohio Valley from other countries. So, he followed the same path as another man named Cloron from four years before. But this time, instead of just hiding important information in the ground, he built and guarded forts. He started by building a fort called Fort Presque Isle near a big lake called Lake Erie. Then, he had a road made from this fort to a special place called LeBoeuf Creek. Next, he built another fort called Fort Le Boeuf, which was meant to protect LeBoeuf Creek. As he traveled south, he scared away or caught some British traders. This made both the British and a group of people called the Iroquois very worried. There was also a chief named Tanaghrisson, who was part of a group called the Mingo. These Mingo people were made up of different tribes that had been pushed out by the growing number of people living in the area. Tanaghrisson really didn't like the French, because he thought they had hurt his dad. So, he went to Fort Le Boeuf and told the French soldiers there that they were in trouble. The French soldiers weren't very worried about this, so they just ignored Tanaghrisson.

1. During the spring of 1753, Paul Marin de la Malgue, a French military leader, was tasked with protecting the King's land in the Ohio Valley from British encroachment. He led a force of 2,000 Troupes de la Marine and indigenous allies on a mission to establish French claims and establish defensive positions. Following the route previously explored by Cloron in 1749, Marin began by constructing Fort Presque Isle, located near present-day Erie, Pennsylvania on the southern shore of Lake Erie. He then established a road leading to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek, and erected a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf, situated in present-day Waterford, Pennsylvania. As he progressed, Marin encountered and expelled British traders, causing alarm among both the British and the Iroquois. In the world of Doctor Who, the producers introduced an intriguing concept that allowed for the seamless transition of the main character's portrayal. This concept was primarily driven by the health concerns of the show's first actor, William Hartnell. Interestingly, the term "regeneration" was not initially associated with this idea; instead, Hartnell's character merely mentioned a "renewal." Meanwhile, the character played by the Second Doctor went through a "change of appearance."

However, it was not until the introduction of the third Doctor that the term "regeneration" came into play, marking a significant evolution in the show's history. This concept has been instrumental in allowing for the successful recasting of the lead actor in the series, as well as providing a means to depict alternative Doctors from different time periods in the character's timeline.

With the introduction of regeneration, Doctor Who has been able to navigate the challenges of casting changes while maintaining the integrity of the beloved show's narrative. This innovative concept has not only facilitated the smooth transition of the main character but also opened up new opportunities for storytelling and character development, further solidifying the show's enduring popularity and impact on popular culture.

title: Victoria and Albert Museum
context: The Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated as the V&A), London, is the world's largest museum of decorative arts and design, housing a permanent collection of over 4.5 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The V&A is located in the Brompton district of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in an area that has become known as "Albertopolis" because of its association with Prince Albert, the Albert Memorial and the major cultural institutions with which he was associated. These include the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum and the Royal Albert Hall. The museum is a non-departmental public body sponsored by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. Like other national British museums, entrance to the museum has been free since 2001.

title: Computational complexity theory
context: But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Computational complexity theory examines the relationship between computation time and machine models, highlighting the differences in time complexities between multi-tape and single-tape Turing machines. The language {xx | x is any binary string} serves as an example, demonstrating that linear time can be achieved on a multi-tape Turing machine, while it requires quadratic time on a single-tape Turing machine. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Computational complexity theory
But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Computational complexity theory is a field of study that deals with the classification of computational problems based on their inherent difficulty, which is often measured by the amount of time or space resources required to solve them. This theory is crucial for understanding the limits of efficient computation and for designing algorithms that can solve problems within these bounds.

The key idea in computational complexity theory is the concept of complexity classes, which are sets of problems that share the same level of difficulty in terms of resource requirements. For example, the complexity class P consists of decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time, meaning the running time of the algorithm is bounded by a polynomial function of the input size.

However, the exact nature of the complexity class can depend on the specific model of computation being used. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but it would require quadratic time in the model of a single-tape Turing machine. This highlights the importance of considering different machine models when studying computational complexity.

One fundamental principle in computational complexity theory is the Cobham-Edmonds thesis, which states that the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related. This means that if we have an algorithm that runs in polynomial time in one model, it will also run in polynomial time in another model, up to a polynomial factor.

This concept leads to the definition of the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. It also has a corresponding class for function problems, denoted as FP, which includes functions that can be computed efficiently by a deterministic Turing machine.

Overall, computational complexity theory provides a framework for understanding the inherent difficulty of computational problems and for classifying them based on their resource requirements. By studying different complexity classes and models of computation, researchers can gain insights into the limits of efficient computation and develop algorithms that can solve problems within these constraints.

Computational complexity theory is a field that deals with the study of the resources required to solve computational problems, such as time and space. However, the exact computation time for a problem can vary depending on the chosen machine model. For example, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but requires quadratic time on a single-tape Turing machine. When considering polynomial variations in running time, the Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related. This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Computational complexity theory is a branch of computer science that focuses on understanding the resources required to solve computational problems. However, the computation time for a problem can vary depending on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but requires quadratic time on a single-tape Turing machine. When considering polynomial variations in running time, the Cobham-Edmonds thesis suggests that the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related. This concept forms the basis for the complexity class P, which consists of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Computational complexity theory
But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

This innovative idea was initially discussed in a presentation called briefing B-265, which was later documented in RAND report P-2626 in 1962 and further detailed in report RM 3420 in 1964. The P-2626 report outlined a comprehensive structure for a large-scale, decentralized, and robust communication network. This work revolves around three crucial concepts: a dispersed network with multiple pathways between any two points, segmentation of user messages into message blocks, also known as packets, and the forwarding of these messages through a store-and-forward mechanism.

The key ideas in Baran's work included a decentralized network design with multiple routes connecting any two points, the division of user messages into message blocks or packets, and the delivery of these packets using a store-and-forward switching method. These concepts laid the foundation for the modern packet-switching technology that we use today.

Rewritten passages:

title: Chloroplast
context: While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain. Normally, the reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP. This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled. Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.

questions.question: What usually takes reenergized electrons?
In what process are electrons recycled?
Where is cyclic photophosphorylation common?
What do C4 plants need?

completions:
1. The Chloroplast is an important part of plant cells that plays a significant role in the process of photosynthesis. One key component of this process is the photolysis of water, which occurs through the action of Photosystem II. This system breaks down water molecules to release electrons, which are then used to power the generation of NADPH and ATP, the energy currency of the cell. However, the electrons produced by Photosystem II can also be redirected to a different location within the electron transport chain, a process known as cyclic photophosphorylation. This alternative pathway allows for the production of ATP without the need to generate NADPH, making it an efficient strategy for certain plant species, such as C4 plants, which have increased energy demands.

2. In the chloroplast, photosynthesis occurs through a complex process involving two photosystems, Photosystem I and Photosystem II. While Photosystem II is responsible for breaking down water molecules to generate electrons, which are then used to produce energy in the form of ATP and NADPH, Photosystem I has a different role. Instead of directly using the electrons produced by Photosystem II, Photosystem I uses them to regenerate depleted electrons, which can then be used to generate more ATP through an electron transport chain. This process is known as cyclic photophosphorylation, and it is a common strategy employed by C4 plants, which require more ATP than NADPH for their energy needs.

3. The chloroplast is a vital component of plant cells, playing a crucial role in photosynthesis, the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy. The graph isomorphism problem is the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic. An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O((n log(n))) for graphs with n vertices.

title: Economic inequality
context: For most of human history higher material living standards  full stomachs, access to clean water and warmth from fuel  led to better health and longer lives. This pattern of higher incomes-longer lives still holds among poorer countries, where life expectancy increases rapidly as per capita income increases, but in recent decades it has slowed down among middle income countries and plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world. Americans live no longer on average (about 77 years in 2004) than Greeks (78 years) or New Zealanders (78), though the USA has a higher GDP per capita. Life expectancy in Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82)  where income was more equally distributed  was longer.

questions.question: What did higher material living standards lead to for most of human history?
Where does the pattern of higher income-longer lives still hold true?
What increases rapidly as per capita income increases?
Who lives no longer on average than Greeks and New Zealanders?
How are incomes distributed in Sweden?

completions:
Economic inequality is a pressing issue in many parts of the world. While historically, higher living standards have led to improved health and longer lives, this pattern has slowed down in middle-income countries and plateaued in the richest nations. In recent years, the USA, despite having a higher GDP per capita, has seen no significant increase in life expectancy (about 77 years in 2004). Countries like Greece and New Zealand, with similar GDP per capita, have slightly longer life expectancies. In comparison, countries with more equitable income distribution, such as Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82 years), have significantly longer life expectancies.

Economic inequality has become a significant concern in today's world. Historically, people with higher living standards, including access to nutritious food, clean water, and fuel, have experienced better health and longer lives. However, in recent decades, the pattern of increased per capita income leading to improved life expectancy has slowed down in middle-income countries and plateaued among the richest nations. The United States, despite having a higher GDP per capita, has seen no significant increase in life expectancy (about 77 years in 2004). In contrast, countries like Greece and New Zealand, with similar levels of GDP per capita, have slightly longer life expectancies. Conversely, countries with more equitable income distribution, such as Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82 years), have significantly longer life expectancies.

Economic inequality is a pressing issue that affects many aspects of society. Historically, higher living standards, including access to food, clean water, and fuel, have been directly linked to improved health and longer lives. However, in recent years, this pattern has changed, with middle-income countries experiencing a slowdown in life expectancy growth and the richest nations seeing a plateau in their life expectancy figures. In the United States, despite its higher GDP per capita, life expectancy remains around 77 years (in 2004). In comparison, countries like Greece and New Zealand, with similar levels of GDP per capita, have slightly longer life expectancies. In contrast, countries with more equitable income distribution, such as Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82 years), have significantly longer life expectancies.

1. Economic inequality has been a persistent issue throughout human history. However, in recent decades, the rate of improvement in life expectancy among middle-income countries has slowed down, and it has plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world. As of 2004, Americans had an average life expectancy of about 77 years, which is comparable to Greeks (78 years) and New Zealanders (78 years), despite having a higher GDP per capita. In Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82 years), where income was more evenly distributed, life expectancy was notably longer.

Rewritten passages:

title: Fresno, California
context: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

title: Martin Luther
context: Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder (or Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (ne Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours. His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council. The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant. He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been close to one of them, Jacob. Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer. He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in 1497, where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498. The three schools focused on the so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic. Luther later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.

title: Kenya
context: The largest share of Kenya's electricity supply comes from hydroelectric stations at dams along the upper Tana River, as well as the Turkwel Gorge Dam in the west. A petroleum-fired plant on the coast, geothermal facilities at Olkaria (near Nairobi), and electricity imported from Uganda make up the rest of the supply. Kenya's installed capacity stood at 1,142 megawatts between 2001 and 2003. The state-owned Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen), established in 1997 under the name of Kenya Power Company, handles the generation of electricity, while Kenya Power handles the electricity transmission and distribution system in the country. Shortfalls of electricity occur periodically, when drought reduces water flow. To become energy sufficient, Kenya aims to build a nuclear power plant by 2017.

Although OPEC's price adjustments to reflect depreciation were slow, from 1947 to 1967, the dollar price of oil had increased by less than two percent per year. Before the oil shock, the price had maintained a relatively stable position against other currencies and commodities. OPEC ministers failed to establish mechanisms to update prices in line with changing market conditions, resulting in their real incomes lagging behind. The price hikes in 1973-1974 primarily restored their prices and corresponding incomes to Bretton Woods levels in terms of commodities such as gold.

title: European Union law
context: To make new legislation, TFEU article 294 defines the "ordinary legislative procedure" that applies for most EU acts. The essence is there are three readings, starting with a Commission proposal, where the Parliament must vote by a majority of all MEPs (not just those present) to block or suggest changes, and the Council must vote by qualified majority to approve changes, but by unanimity to block Commission amendment. Where the different institutions cannot agree at any stage, a "Conciliation Committee" is convened, representing MEPs, ministers and the Commission to try and get agreement on a joint text: if this works, it will be sent back to the Parliament and Council to approve by absolute and qualified majority. This means, legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament, a minority in the Council, and a majority in the Commission: it is harder to change EU law than stay the same. A different procedure exists for budgets. For "enhanced cooperation" among a sub-set of at least member states, authorisation must be given by the Council. Member state governments should be informed by the Commission at the outset before any proposals start the legislative procedure. The EU as a whole can only act within its power set out in the Treaties. TEU articles 4 and 5 state that powers remain with the member states unless they have been conferred, although there is a debate about the Kompetenz-Kompetenz question: who ultimately has the "competence" to define the EU's "competence". Many member state courts believe they decide, other member state Parliaments believe they decide, while within the EU, the Court of Justice believes it has the final say.

Article 294 of this treaty defines the "ordinary legislative procedure," which is used for creating new EU legislation. This process involves multiple stages, beginning with a proposal from the European Commission. During the first reading, the European Parliament must vote on whether to approve the proposal, with the majority of all Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) required for a decision. The ordinary legislative procedure, as defined by article 294 of the TFEU, is the primary method for creating new EU legislation. This process involves multiple readings, starting with a proposal from the Commission, followed by a vote by the Parliament to either accept or suggest changes. The Council must then approve or block these changes through a qualified majority vote, with the Council having the power to block the Commission's proposed amendments through a unanimous vote. If the institutions cannot reach an agreement at any stage, a Conciliation Committee is formed, comprising representatives from the Parliament, Council, and Commission, to attempt to reconcile the differences and produce a joint text. This joint text is then sent back to the Parliament and Council for final approval by absolute and qualified majorities.

A different procedure is used for EU budgets. For enhanced cooperation among at least 19 member states, authorization is required from the Council. Member states are informed of any proposed legislation by the Commission at the outset. The EU can only act within the powers granted to it by the Treaties, with TEU articles 4 and 5 stating that powers are vested in the member states unless explicitly conferred upon the EU. However, there is debate over the concept of Kompetenz-Kompetenz, which refers to the question of who ultimately decides on the EU's competence. While member state courts, parliaments, and the Court of Justice have different opinions, the ultimate decision is considered to lie with the Court of Justice.

title: Apollo program
context: The plugs-out test began on the morning of January 27, 1967, and immediately was plagued with problems. First the crew noticed a strange odor in their spacesuits, which delayed the sealing of the hatch. Then, communications problems frustrated the astronauts and forced a hold in the simulated countdown. During this hold, an electrical fire began in the cabin, and spread quickly in the high pressure, 100% oxygen atmosphere. Pressure rose high enough from the fire that the cabin burst and the fire erupted onto the pad area, frustrating attempts to rescue the crew. The astronauts were asphyxiated before the hatch could be opened.

The papacy in relation to the Bible
Pope Leo X, a seasoned leader familiar with reformers and heretics, responded to Luther with a measured approach, stating that he would handle the situation with "great care as is proper." Over the next three years, Leo employed a succession of papal theologians and envoys to combat Luther, a move that inadvertently reinforced Luther's anti-papal beliefs. One of these theologians, the Dominican Sylvester Mazzolini, prepared a case against Luther, leading Leo to summon the reformer to Rome. However, the Elector Frederick intervened, persuading the pope to have Luther examined at Augsburg, where the Imperial Diet was convened. At the Augsburg Diet in October 1518, under questioning by papal legate Cardinal Cajetan, Luther asserted that he did not view the papacy as a part of the biblical Church due to his historical interpretation of Bible prophecy, which identified the papacy as the Antichrist. This central debate over the prophecies concerning the Antichrist led to a heated exchange between Luther and Cajetan. The hearings descended into a heated argument. Unlike his initial instructions, which had been to arrest Luther if he refused to recant, Cajetan ultimately refrained from taking action. Consequently, Luther managed to escape the city unnoticed during the night, remaining unaware of Cajetan's intentions.

context: The United Methodist Church is one tradition within the Christian Church. The United Methodist Church is active in ecumenical relations with other Christian groups and denominations. Many Hui Muslims claim this is because that they played an important role in overthrowing the Mongols and it was given in thanks by the Han Chinese for assisting them. During the war fighting the Mongols, among the Ming Emperor Zhu Yuanzhang's armies was the Hui Muslim Feng Sheng. The Muslims in the semu class also revolted against the Yuan dynasty in the Ispah Rebellion but the rebellion was crushed and the Muslims were massacred by the Yuan loyalist commander Chen Youding.

title: Construction
context: A construction project is a complex net of contracts and other legal obligations, each of which all parties must carefully consider. A contract is the exchange of a set of obligations between two or more parties, but it is not so simple a matter as trying to get the other side to agree to as much as possible in exchange for as little as possible. The time element in construction means that a delay costs money, and in cases of bottlenecks, the delay can be extremely expensive. Thus, the contracts must be designed to ensure that each side is capable of performing the obligations set out. Contracts that set out clear expectations and clear paths to accomplishing those expectations are far more likely to result in the project flowing smoothly, whereas poorly drafted contracts lead to confusion and collapse.

title: European Union law
context: While the Commission has a monopoly on initiating legislation, the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have powers of amendment and veto during the legislative process. According to the Treaty on European Union articles 9 and 10, the EU observes "the principle of equality of its citizens" and is meant to be founded on "representative democracy". In practice, equality and democracy are deficient because the elected representatives in the Parliament cannot initiate legislation against the Commission's wishes, citizens of smallest countries have ten times the voting weight in Parliament as citizens of the largest countries, and "qualified majorities" or consensus of the Council are required to legislate. The justification for this "democratic deficit" under the Treaties is usually thought to be that completion integration of the European economy and political institutions required the technical coordination of experts, while popular understanding of the EU developed and nationalist sentiments declined post-war. Over time, this has meant the Parliament gradually assumed more voice: from being an unelected assembly, to its first direct elections in 1979, to having increasingly more rights in the legislative process. Citizens' rights are therefore limited compared to the democratic polities within all European member states: under TEU article 11 citizens and associations have the rights such as publicising their views and submit an initiative that must be considered by the Commission with one million signatures. TFEU article 227 contains a further right for citizens to petition the Parliament on issues which affect them. Parliament elections, take place every five years, and votes for Members of the European Parliament in member states must be organised by proportional representation or a single transferable vote. There are 750 MEPs and their numbers are "degressively proportional" according to member state size. This means - although the Council is meant to be the body representing member states - in the Parliament citizens of smaller member states have more voice than citizens in larger member states. MEPs divide, as they do in national Parliaments, along political party lines: the conservative European People's Party is currently the largest, and the Party of European Socialists leads the opposition. Parties do not receive public funds from the EU, as the Court of Justice held in Parti cologiste "Les Verts" v Parliament that this was entirely an issue to be regulated by the member states. The Parliament's powers include calling inquiries into maladministration or appoint an Ombudsman pending any court proceedings. It can require the Commission respond to questions and by a two-thirds majority can censure the whole Commission (as happened to the Santer Commission in 1999). In some cases, the Parliament has explicit consultation rights, which the Commission must genuinely follow. However its role participation in the legislative process still remains limited because no member can actually or pass legislation without the Commission and Council, meaning power ("kratia") is not in the hands of directly elected representatives of the people ("demos"): in the EU it is not yet true that "the administration is in the hands of the many and not of the few."

questions.answer: cannot initiate legislation against the Commission's wishes

Passage:
European Union law
While the Commission has a monopoly on initiating legislation, the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have powers of amendment and veto during the legislative process. According to the Treaty on European Union articles 9 and 10, the EU observes "the principle of equality of its citizens" and is meant to be founded on "representative democracy". In practice, equality and democracy are deficient because the elected representatives in the Parliament cannot initiate legislation against the Commission's wishes, citizens of smallest countries have ten times the voting weight in Parliament as citizens of the largest countries, and "qualified majorities" or consensus of the Council are required to legislate. The justification for this "democratic deficit" under the Treaties is usually thought to be that completion integration of the European economy and political institutions required the technical coordination of experts, while popular understanding of the EU developed and nationalist sentiments declined post-war. Over time, this has meant the Parliament gradually assumed more voice: from being an unelected assembly, to its first direct elections in 1979, to having increasingly more rights in the legislative process. Citizens' rights are therefore limited compared to the democratic polities within all European member states: under TEU article 11 citizens and associations have the rights such as publicising their views and submit an initiative that must be considered by the Commission with one million signatures. TFEU article 227 contains a further right for citizens to petition the Parliament on issues which affect them. Parliament elections, take place every five years, and votes for Members of the European Parliament in member states must be organised by proportional representation or a single transferable vote. There are 750 MEPs and their numbers are "degressively proportional" according to member state size. This means - although the Council is meant to be the body representing member states - in the Parliament citizens of smaller member states have more voice than citizens in larger member states. MEPs divide, as they do in national Parliaments, along political party lines: the conservative European People's Party is currently the largest, and the Party of European Socialists leads the opposition. Parties do not receive public funds from the EU, as the Court of Justice held in Parti cologiste "Les Verts" v Parliament that this was entirely an issue to be regulated by the member states. The Parliament's powers include calling inquiries into maladministration or appoint an Ombudsman pending any court proceedings. It can require the Commission respond to questions and by a two-thirds majority can censure the whole Commission (as happened to the Santer Commission in 1999). In some cases, the Parliament has explicit consultation rights, which the Commission must genuinely follow. However its role participation in the legislative process still remains limited because no member can actually or pass legislation without the Commission and Council, meaning power ("kratia") is not in the hands of directly elected representatives of the people ("demos"): in the EU it is not yet true that "the administration is in the hands of the many and not of the few."

The Social Charter, which consists of 30 general principles, such as fair employment remuneration, workplace health and safety, rights of the elderly and disabled, and workers' rights, as well as provisions for vocational training and living conditions, serves as the foundation for 40 pieces of legislation. These legislative measures contribute to the European Community's pursuit of a more equitable and prosperous future for its citizens.

Rewritten passages:

title: Victoria and Albert Museum
context: Well represented in the collection is Meissen porcelain, from the first factory in Europe to discover the Chinese method of making porcelain. Among the finest examples are the Meissen Vulture from 1731 and the Mllendorff Dinner Service, designed in 1762 by Frederick II the Great. Ceramics from the Manufacture nationale de Svres are extensive, especially from the 18th and 19th centuries. The collection of 18th-century British porcelain is the largest and finest in the world. Examples from every factory are represented, the collections of Chelsea porcelain and Worcester Porcelain being especially fine. All the major 19th-century British factories are also represented. A major boost to the collections was the Salting Bequest made in 1909, which enriched the museum's stock of Chinese and Japanese ceramics. This bequest forms part of the finest collection of East Asian pottery and porcelain in the world, including Kakiemon ware.

Which part of the V&A collection did the Salting Bequest enhanced?

Each rewritten passage retains the same information and meaning as the original passage but presents it in a different style, tone, or structure.

### Passage 1
Computational complexity theory
When dealing with computational problems, the input size often determines the amount of time required to solve them. This relationship can be expressed as a function of n, where n represents the size of the input. However, since different inputs of the same size may require varying amounts of time to process, the worst-case time complexity T(n) is defined as the maximum time taken across all inputs of size n. An algorithm is considered to be a polynomial time algorithm if its time complexity, T(n), can be represented by a polynomial in terms of n. According to Cobham's thesis, a problem is considered solvable with a feasible amount of resources if it has a polynomial time algorithm.

### Passage 2
Computational complexity theory
In the context of computational complexity theory, the time taken by an algorithm to solve a problem is closely tied to the size of its input, denoted as n. This relationship can be described using a function that captures the time required for various inputs of size n. However, because different inputs of the same size might have varying processing times, the worst-case time complexity T(n) is defined as the highest time taken among all inputs of size n. If T(n) can be expressed as a polynomial function of n, the algorithm is classified as a polynomial time algorithm. Cobham's thesis posits that a problem is computationally feasible if it possesses a polynomial time algorithm.

### Passage 3
Computational complexity theory
Within computational complexity theory, understanding the time taken by algorithms to solve problems becomes crucial. This time is influenced by the size of the input, represented as n. To account for this, the time taken can be described through a function that reflects the processing time for different inputs of size n. Nevertheless, due to potential differences in processing times for identical input sizes, the worst-case time complexity T(n) is defined as the greatest time taken across all inputs of size n. An algorithm is deemed a polynomial time algorithm when its time complexity, T(n), can be expressed as a polynomial function of n. According to Cobham's thesis, a problem is considered computationally solvable with a reasonable amount of resources if it exhibits a polynomial time algorithm.

title: Sky (United Kingdom)
context: BSkyB initially charged additional subscription fees for using a Sky+ PVR with their service; waiving the charge for subscribers whose package included two or more premium channels. This changed as from 1 July 2007, and now customers that have Sky+ and subscribe to any BSkyB subscription package get Sky+ included at no extra charge. Customers that do not subscribe to BSkyB's channels can still pay a monthly fee to enable Sky+ functions. In January 2010 BSkyB discontinued the Sky+ Box, limited the standard Sky Box to Multiroom upgrade only and started to issue the Sky+HD Box as standard, thus giving all new subscribers the functions of Sky+. In February 2011 BSkyB discontinued the non-HD variant of its Multiroom box, offering a smaller version of the SkyHD box without Sky+ functionality. In September 2007, Sky launched a new TV advertising campaign targeting Sky+ at women. As of 31 March 2008, Sky had 3,393,000 Sky+ users.

title: United Methodist Church

To be recognized as local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic course for lay servant. To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. They must report and reapply annually; and they must complete at least one advanced course every three years.

title: Teacher
context: The objective is typically accomplished through either an informal or formal approach to learning, including a course of study and lesson plan that teaches skills, knowledge and/or thinking skills. Different ways to teach are often referred to as pedagogy. When deciding what teaching method to use teachers consider students' background knowledge, environment, and their learning goals as well as standardized curricula as determined by the relevant authority. Many times, teachers assist in learning outside of the classroom by accompanying students on field trips. The increasing use of technology, specifically the rise of the internet over the past decade, has begun to shape the way teachers approach their roles in the classroom.
